question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First, I learned way more about the US and Global regulatory pathways than I could have ever imaged. Although, I still have some confusion on the payment/reimbursement pathways, I feel much more confident with that information and am motivated to pursue that topic on my own further. I have also been surprised by the level of consideration and detail that goes into the business plan/regulatory roadmap and I have gained a greater appreciation for the thoughtful and accurate execution of these plans.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was extremely informative about how medical products go from an idea to the market. Before this class, I knew nothing about how medical products get FDA approval and reimbursed by insurance- I only knew that the FDA and insurance were things. Through this course, I learned a great detail about how medical products receive FDA approval, the process they undergo to get reimbursed, and the dynamics between these two processes. Going through the final project too helped greatly illuminate all of the various components that must be considered when trying to get a product to market.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

FDA regulations to get a product approved

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dr. Silcox asks pretty difficult questions; you'll learn a lot, but if you don't have previous knowledge on healthcare policy this course definitely "throws you in the deep end" a bit. It gets into granular details about regulation and reimbursement, so it's helpful if you have some background on it already.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

You will be told things like, "don't explain xyz like an engineer" rather than asked how to relate your field to the course content.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Thought about dead people more and what death means, looking at death in different ways, comparing life and death

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Analytical thinking, creative thinking, close reading

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how cultural anthropology is structured, and was able to look at life and death through that lens. In particular, I learned more about funeral rites from other countries, moral and ethical dilemmas surrounding care of the dying or dead, and how different cultures approach both life and death.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think about life and death in a different sense, looking at how things relate in a way I never thought about before, and what life and death truly means.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think from the perspective of someone who is about to die, and I learned how to read papers with a critical eye yet understanding perspective where I attempt to understand both sides of an argument. I also learned about different cultures and unique traditions they might have that may sound bizarre to me but have value to the people in that culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Reading texts from foreign cultures critically but with understanding of different social norms
2) Understanding how the value of death and life are linked through culture, law, science, and politics
3) Feeling death as a social and not simply individual experience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about other cultures' perceptions of life and death, particularly Japan's.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to identify broader patterns of behavior within and across cultures around the world.
2. How to write an ethnographic research paper.
3. A new understanding of life and death and why it is important to destigmitize conversations about death.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how people think about life and death in different cultures.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped conceptualize and ask the deeper, gritty questions related to life and death. This course gave great insights into how we both understand where we put ourselves in the grand schema of rituals related to life and death but also how we ask questions and critically analyze why these types of rituals are done.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- New insights around ideas of life and death: this course has provided me with a completely new perspective on notions of death and dying in the U.S. and elsewhere 
- Knowledge about different death rituals among different cultures, demonstrating the variety that exists but how humans universally seem to have a need (for both the living and the dead) to practice rituals around death 
- Text analysis and writing skills in completing written assignments that required us to use the texts provided to us to draw upon our class discussions and bring in new ideas to create a written reflection/paper

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned more about the various ways to view death, life, and the dying process. We examined many anthropological aspects of the process of dying and what that may mean for both the dead and the grieving living.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Different ways of viewing death based on culture/practices
- Necropolitics
- How relevant these practices are in our day to day life

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was very analytical. It teaches you how to analyze complex topics and think about them critically in multiple contexts. This class also develops your introspective thinking and forcing you to engage with the materialfrom a personal viewpoint.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about some different cultural aspects pertaining to death and the rituals of death, the divergences of the dying regarding what happens to them, and societal's roles concerning the dead and ensuring a "good death."

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, we learn about the different aspects of life and death as stated in the description. We delve into topics dealing with how politics influences our births (roe v wade), life care (what policies exist either in healthcare or pensions for us to be taken of during the final moments of our lifes, so our families don't have to have the burden, and even death (who/what decides whether we are buried, cremated, etc. We also explore how different cultures view and treat death differently (which is dependent on their generation) with different rituals like some will perform cannibalism on their deceased loved ones, while others due to time will prefer their loved ones to be in a columbarium over their ancestor's grave, the significance of the bones/bodies to be able to mourn properly the deceased, etc. I was informed a little more about the world and the issues that can be of big impact like for instance that in china there is a huge old population while in Africa, there is a huge youth population.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have a deeper understanding of attitudes towards life and death from different regions and countries, including the concept of good death and bad death, the proper way of treating people with dementia and the process of after-life care and mourning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how to think about life and death in a nuanced context. I also strengthened my ethnographic and research skills as a cultural anthropologist.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- The differences between illness and disease

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- In this course I learned how medical anthropology has evolved over the centuries and how the impact of anthropology in medicine has shown a difference in how medicine operates.
Understanding Illness as Culturally Constructed: One of the most impactful insights I gained is that illness is not just a biological event—it’s shaped by cultural beliefs, social systems, and power structures. This helped me see how different societies interpret symptoms, causes, and healing in distinct ways, which really shifted how I think about health and medicine.
Structural Violence and Health Inequities

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First, I learned what an ethnography is and how to read challenging texts. Second, I learned how to write essays with challenging texts. Third and most importantly, I learned how to do ethnographic research and I found it really valuable. As a stem major, I've done other forms of more technical research and in my other humanities classes I've done research in the sense of citing books, article, etc. This was very different than anything I've done before, because I had to interview people. This changed my trajectory because I didn't want to do those other kind of research, but now i know this is an option that perhaps I would want to pursue in the future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

This approach helped me better understand why some policies succeed in certain contexts and fail in others.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Additionally, your grade truly depends on which professor you have grading your paper which is beyond unfair and annoying.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the most impactful insights I developed was the importance of systems thinking when evaluating health interventions. Rather than viewing public health issues in isolation, the course taught me to consider how various elements—such as financing, human resources, service delivery, and governance—interact in complex ways. This approach helped me better understand why some policies succeed in certain contexts and fail in others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I thought this class was a great way to gain a substantial toolbox for Global Health in the context of policy, and governmental organizations.I learned a lot about the interworkings of governmental systems and their obligations to health. I also learned a lot about really popular health policies (ie. Universal Healthcare) and the feasibility of implementing such on both national and international scales.I also just felt like a lot of previous knowledge on the history of health (ie. the creation of global health, the push for health agendas) were all reinforced during this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was able to learn that many of the public health/global health issues that are high on the global health agenda are products of funding - many of the issues seen today have a tie to the economic decisions are many countries. I also learned how to dissect a policy (i.e., understanding the key players). Lastly, I learned that there is still so much work to do in the world of global health.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: I loved the lectures and I think Prof Boucher does a great job making the long lectures entertaining and interesting. I enjoyed the discussion posts as I think they help students learn, think, and assess their own opinions on topics. I think my favorite part of the class was the group presentations. All the groups picked very interesting healthcare issues and I enjoyed getting to learn about some of the specific topics in our healthcare system that were not covered in class. I also appreciate not having a final. Having tests would change the dynamic of the class. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think this is a fascinating course, I can really see how it's the starting point for the health policy certificate. Sometimes, you might find yourself more curious about the global perspective (which I guess is Global Health), but those thoughts dissipate once you're drawn into the complexities of the U.S. health care system. It's a really fun and insightful class, but it can also be a bit draining too. It's sad to hear about policies actively working against providing universal health care access, and it's even worse to hear about specific issues we're too powerless to change. Regardless, this course was quite outstanding, both in its material and the professor, and I would certainly recommend it!

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I'd highly recommend this class for anyone who may be interested in health policy or going into a health profession in the future (aka premeds- you should take this course)! It wasn't a whole bunch of work with the way Prof Campbell set up the course. We had weekly reflections, three assignments spread out throughout the semester, and a final project. The weekly reflections took me longer than I initially thought it would (3-5 hours, including reading the assigned articles + writing), but I learned so much.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Come to class prepared with things to say about the readings and prepare to steer the discussion. If there is something you would like to get out of the class, make that clear. Dr. Campbell was very open-minded and open to feedback.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was a great introduction to the US healthcare system, with complex topics and debates ranging from abortion to healthcare insurance coverage. We discussed the dominance of employer-sponsored insurance and US health spend compared globally. I would recommend the course to anyone interested in health policy, community health, and medicine!

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is very interesting and manageable for students of all majors. It provides a lot of insight into how healthcare works in the US particularly, but also in a more general sense. It has been helpful in shaping my understanding of how things like insurance, quality of care etc are managed, which I think are important and applicable to the near future when I have to make health decisions for myself.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write better argumentative essays by thinking about counterarguments and poking holes in it to bring back the point. I learned how biases present themselves in studies. I learned about the U.S. healthcare landscape and the many factors that have influenced its becoming.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to put my own personal beliefs aside and write objectively, even if I did not agree with the stance I was taking. I also learned about the various considerations that go into policy decisions and that it will be much more difficult to reform healthcare than I previous thought.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed an ability to critically weigh benefits and drawbacks of the American healthcare system, and to evaluate my ideas with sufficient rigor. The latter point was an emphasis of the class, which I greatly appreciated as I potentially consider a career in health policy.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Dr. Ubel's style of "cold calling" students in class helped me to think on me feet, stay engaged, allow my opinions and ideas to be challenged, and use critical thinking skills. Additionally, the "impossible to answer" essay prompts made me think more broadly and precisely.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically think about the US healthcare system. We did this through readings, quizzes, and essays, as well as in class participation. I learned numerous insights into just how complicated the US healthcare system truly is, and how it converges with the field of economics. We studied cost, quality, and access extensively, and critically evaluated what aspects should be tackled in order to fix a flawed system.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about the US healthcare system and its pros and cons. The essays make you question what you think is true and then decide how to best refute opposing views. I learned to be much more critical of what our current systems in place are and that even though the US is doing something does not make it the right thing to do. I also learned to concisely get points across, especially when the topics can be hard to discuss.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-- Knowledge about the basic structures of the US healthcare system, including private insurers, CMS, drug manufacturers/pharmacies/PBMs, etc. Some comparison to other countries
-- How incentives modify the behavior of patients, physicians, hospitals, insurers, and so on 
-- Various payment systemts, attempted reforms, and ongoing research into future models of health care

response_text: The course was taught in person once a week (for 2.5 hours) and it was very effective. Each lecture consisted of an informative lecture. response_text: The smaller class size was nice because we could speak freely. I liked being able to jump in with questions, though cold calling could be a little nerve wracking. It is an easy, interesting class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the most impactful insights I developed was the importance of systems thinking when evaluating health interventions. Rather than viewing public health issues in isolation, the course taught me to consider how various elements—such as financing, human resources, service delivery, and governance—interact in complex ways. This approach helped me better understand why some policies succeed in certain contexts and fail in others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Universal Healthcare) and the feasibility of implementing such on both national and international scales.I also just felt like a lot of previous knowledge on the history of health (ie. the creation of global health, the push for health agendas) were all reinforced during this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the most impactful insights I developed was the importance of systems thinking when evaluating health interventions. Rather than viewing public health issues in isolation, the course taught me to consider how various elements—such as financing, human resources, service delivery, and governance—interact in complex ways. This approach helped me better understand why some policies succeed in certain contexts and fail in others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I thought this class was a great way to gain a substantial toolbox for Global Health in the context of policy, and governmental organizations.I learned a lot about the interworkings of governmental systems and their obligations to health. I also learned a lot about really popular health policies (ie. Universal Healthcare) and the feasibility of implementing such on both national and international scales.I also just felt like a lot of previous knowledge on the history of health (ie. the creation of global health, the push for health agendas) were all reinforced during this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also learned how to dissect a policy (i.e., understanding the key players). Lastly, I learned that there is still so much work to do in the world of global health.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three things that I developed/learned during the course had to do with the Latino/poc community. I learned about the cultural competence and how its important for people who are trying to go into the medical field because everyone needs to be treated with respect and sometimes working with people from different backgrounds may need for different handling techniques. I also learned about the need for interpreters and translators. Finally, I also learned about the need to speak other languages other than English especially in this ever-growing country.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that acting out of your comfort zone can sometimes be very helpful to other people and although some questions may seem intrusive, they are actually very beneficial to learning about people and their lifestyles. I also learned that cultural competence is not only learning to speak another language but engaging in that culture and that culture mastery can never be achieved. Lastly, I learned that a person in Latina America is in fact, American and that this term should not be used for only those in the United States.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about specific aspects that are similarities among much of latino culture and the vast vast differences that exist within it too (diversity). I learned about the inequities facing latino immigrants in the United States and how that impacts their ability to gain accessible and quality health care. I learned how to best continue improving my cultural competence of latino culture as to increase ability to work with latino people in our community with sympathy and an open-mind.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned about disparities affecting the health of latino people, particularly in the United States

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class gave me incredible real-world application of common health disparities both in and out of the US. A few main takeaways: learning about the social determinants of health, traditional medicine, and the Latino Paradox.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about social determinants of health in the Latina community. Through service learning, I learned how health and culture interact in the Latina community in Durham.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Specifically, I learned about the extent and dynamics of food insecurity in the country, and especially in North Carolina and Durham. I learned new vocabulary and correcting common grammatical errors that I was making. I also learned about many different service organizations both locally and nationally (such as TCG, Iglesia Emanuel, Root Causes, etc...) that worked to address social determinants of health.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to speak more fluent and conversational Spanish through various modalities inside and outside the classroom. I learned more about the general health disparities that Latine persons face inside and outside of the United States, through various theories/frameworks but also personal stories from communities. Lastly, I learned how these health topics were related to the Latine population in Durham through engaging in and reflecting on service learning with the Latine community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about social determinants of health from the Latino and immigrant perspectives. I learned about how where you live impacts the food you have access to and the amount of daily stress you are under from violence or lack of public parks. I also learned about the immigrant paradox and potential explanations for why recently immigrated Latinos are healthier than Latinos who have been in the US for longer. I also learned about service learning and the value of learning about complex issues alongside actual community engagement.

The course prioritized learning the content more so that the final grade which I believe is a good attribute in a class of pre-meds/Global Health/PubPol majors who are aiming to learn how to provide better care or create better polices to improve healthcare outcomes. Joan did a great job covering the complexities of Latino health in America from urban and rural struggles, ACEs, exclusion because of documentation status, mental health, determinants of health, holistic health, and so much more in a way that was understandable in another language, giving us a deep understanding of this community.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: A good amount of the partner organizations work on the weekends or during regular class hours so there may be some conflicts if you have a lot of classes back to back or commitments on the weekends. So, be prepared to manage a long term service commitment around this -- that is have a plan before taking the course that also accommodates your other projected semester commitments (and some wiggle room for unexpected events) to make sure you are able to enjoy that aspect of the class and doesn't become a point of stress.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Once halfway through the course, it is more about application of that learned knowledge, so it becomes more creative and more fun. The service learning portion also made the course a lot more meaningful and engaging because you are getting the change to directly interact with the community in a way that matters; this engagement also made me want to engage more in the course material so I could apply it in the service learning portion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned the challenges and the barriers that confront the Latino community in the US and Latin American countries. We learned about the Latino Health paradox, acculturation, and assimilation and their effects on Latino health and its connection with immigration. We also constructed and discussed different health policy interventions that can improve Latino health in the US.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I developed valuable discussion and comprehension skills in Spanish and expanded my conversational level of Spanish to a level where I can discuss more complex issues in depth with diverse vocabulary.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think about life and death in a different sense, looking at how things relate in a way I never thought about before, and what life and death truly means.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also learned about different cultures and unique traditions they might have that may sound bizarre to me but have value to the people in that culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

3) Feeling death as a social and not simply individual experience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

- Text analysis and writing skills in completing written assignments that required us to use the texts provided to us to draw upon our class discussions and bring in new ideas to create a written reflection/paper

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, we learn about the different aspects of life and death as stated in the description. We delve into topics dealing with how politics influences our births (roe v wade), life care (what policies exist either in healthcare or pensions for us to be taken of during the final moments of our lifes, so our families don't have to have the burden, and even death (who/what decides whether we are buried, cremated, etc. We also explore how different cultures view and treat death differently (which is dependent on their generation) with different rituals like some will perform cannibalism on their deceased loved ones, while others due to time will prefer their loved ones to be in a columbarium over their ancestor's grave, the significance of the bones/bodies to be able to mourn properly the deceased, etc. I was informed a little more about the world and the issues that can be of big impact like for instance that in china there is a huge old population while in Africa, there is a huge youth population.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have a deeper understanding of attitudes towards life and death from different regions and countries, including the concept of good death and bad death, the proper way of treating people with dementia and the process of after-life care and mourning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how to think about life and death in a nuanced context. I also strengthened my ethnographic and research skills as a cultural anthropologist.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Through the course, I was able to learn how to speak to patients in a way that is engaging and allows them to openly share their feelings and thoughts (ex. not question stacking, open ended questions, etc.)
I also learned the methodology of a systematic review from start to finish, going from creating a question to screening and extracting data.
This project has taught me the importance of communication, between members of this project as team members, but also on a larger scale between a doctor and their patients. Keeping a line open can take on multiple forms, like MyChart, phone calls, follow up appointments, etc., but it is essential for patients to feel comfortable and get the best care possible.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: (1) In this past fall semester, I have learned information and facts regarding Spine Surgery.  I have learned to differentiate between different surgery types and understand more of the recovery process.(2) I have a lot more experience in communicating well with my research team.(3) I grew a lot in understanding what is required to carry out a systematic review. The process at first was a little daunting but through amazing guidance and support it was a lot more digestible and encouraging to carry out.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to write a systematic review, patient education, and the importance of physical therapy after spine surgery procedures.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating because it required me to learn many new skills and push my comfort zone by calling patients and conducting a systematic review.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I knew recovering from a surgery takes its time, but it is different seeing it unravel in your own eyes. It is also different when deeply understanding that each case has its own contributing factors. These contributing factors can make drastic differences. For example, the background history of the patient can change the starting point for recovery after spine surgery. A patient may not have much mobility before surgery, so it is not expected for much mobility advancement to happen right after surgery when compared to someone who has more mobility experience in surgery. Yet, even with more prior mobility experience, the process of surgery recovery is still a long road. Main takeaway:  It is not possible to take a cookie-cutter approach to every surgery and recovery, so to say that this set of steps/lifestyles before and after can help surgery is an outdated idea that I was impressed with. Each case is different and therefore has its own unique steps.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The systematic review, lectures, and patient calls made this course very, very stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It offers extremely unique opportunities to simultaneously meaningfully interact with patients as an undergraduate and publish a systematic review. I believe that no other Bass Connections or undergraduate class has offered this before, and thus I found it very intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating because it had a lot of guest speakers within the medical field who shared their personal experiences or explained the facts behind the social determinants of health, the healthcare system, etc. Such material is relevant to the world around me, which is the most important part of a class in my opinion.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: One of my favorite experiences at Duke! The mix between research and patient focuses is a great balance and everyone involved in leading the program is wonderful.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: These are profound experiences that can change your aspect of the importance of being a navigator. I loved that we were able to support that patient as a navigator. There was one visit in which we got (big huge credit to Jaqueline) to request a bed checkup for the patient. About 6-7 minutes, there was a bed checkup and it was decided to swap out the bed of the patient since it would not inflate. It was impactful to see. Also seeing how we bring conversation to the patient is something else I enjoyed participating in. It can be a little disappointing to be stuck between four hospital walls, and I think having some sort of conversation with other individuals can help make the patient better. Social support is very important, and to know that we are part of the support for this patient is a reward on its own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: During this course, I developed a deeper understanding of how intra-operative and post-operative pain management regimens impact functional mobility after lumbar spine surgery. In doing so, I gained valuable skills in conducting systematic reviews, such as extracting data and analyzing study quality. Additionally, participating in patient visits through a navigators program provided hands-on insight into the challenges patients face, reinforcing the importance of connecting clinical research with real-world experiences to inform equitable healthcare solutions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much in this class. I learned very specific legal and medical information, and challenged and expanded my understanding on reproductive justice. I also learned new qualitative research methods, like oral history, which has given me skills that are translatable to other research initiatives. For the first time, this course gave me the opportunity to produce public-facing knowledge, and improved my writing and communication skills through various publishing opportunities. Initially, this course also changed my thinking of team research, showing me how to incorporate diverse perspectives in which everyone is a leader.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so many things in this course it's hard to pinpoint what was the most important or insightful. Hard skills wise, I learned how to create brand kits, social media kits, and do a purpose analysis (using StoryBrand). I also learned how to use Elementor and create websites on Wordpress. I also learned how to complete oral history interviews, transcribe properly, and code. Overall, though, I learned so much about reproductive care and the history of gynecology, and the way in which legislators and policy has impacted care access today. Additionally, I learned invaluable information on what doctors are enduring post roe and the upending impacts of that on not only healthcare systems but current patients, and future generations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Racialized history of Ob/Gyn
2. Oral history interview techniques
3. Deeper understanding of abortion policies in the U.S. and their implications

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have grown in more ways that I can articulate through this class. To name only three specific things: 1) I have developed an understanding of oral history methodologies and how documenting living history can be a powerful method of archiving our current experiences to share with future generations, 2) I've learned how to analyze and visualize quantitative data using Excel and Tableau, extracting important themes and identifying meaningful trends, and 3) I've gained a rich understanding of the systemic barriers that may hinder certain populations from accessing affordable and equitable reproductive care, as well as how advocates such as students, people who can get pregnant, physicians, economists, and journalists, alike may facilitate this movement.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course facilitated my learning by providing readings, resources, practitioner interactions, discussions, and opportunities for reflection. I would keep all of these, but maybe also include community engagement at RJ events or at organizational spaces outside of Duke so the team can be more connected to RJ in Durham.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors and grad mentors were the best I could have ever asked for. The fall semester structure where we learned the medical, legal, social, and historical background of reproductive care and the OBGYN field while setting up each sector of the project (media, interview, data team) was incredible. The spring semester action oriented class time was useful. We stayed up to date on current events and discussed workflow for the overall team and that had time to collaborate across groups. I think this structure is very helpful for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
-Team building and an appropriate amount of time for just getting to know each other. Feeling closer to the team helped us have more synergy working together.
-Sub-team meetings and allocating more time to sub-teams in the spring semester was helpful.
-Really nice to have such a diverse group of interests/fields represented on the team, from social work to medicine to AAAS, etc.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our class functioned in three specific subteams focused on data collection, media production, and interview conduction. Though each team operated independently with a set list of tasks, there was also a lot of cross-collaboration between the teams. Our class time was used to 1) provide foundational knowledge about the work, 2) work across subteams, 3) foster personal relationships and 4) plan the next steps of the project. I feel that this method of instruction was highly effective and allowed us to meet deadlines, work quickly, become familiar with each other's preferred communication styles, and play into each individual team member's unique set of skills and knowledge.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Hogan cultivated a learning environment that was welcoming and encouraged growth. She recognized that we all had different skills coming onto the team and that they all were valuable. All of our voices were heard and seen as important and that helped with learning in the classroom.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that we had to be prepared to lead discussion on the material we had to read in class. I also like how we concurrently had whole-class assignments and subteam assignments. This was useful because the whole class assignments kept us together as a team while we all specialized in our subteam assignments.

response_text: This class made me think about what I envision the future to look like. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the capacity to interpret and learn laws and restriction surrounding reproductive healthcare, I gain skills in conducting oral history interviews, and I gained an immense amount of knowledge about the reproductive landscape of the world, during arguably one of the most important times.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was able to practice data collection for large sets (>700 unique variables). This helped me hone my analysis skills as well as presentation skills by giving me the opportunity to present at symposiums during the semester.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed research skills, critical thinking skills and so many others. This class definitely expanded my way of thinking and the way I approach the topic of reproductive healthcare. I learned that abortions are way less common than what most people think, I learned about the very important history of reproductive healthcare and about all the health disparities between different racial and socioeconomic groups.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how to cultivate my oral history interviewing skills
2) I learned so much more about the current climate for reproductive healthcare providers and the challenges they face day to day due to abortion restrictions
3) I learned how to communicate complex topics in a more digestible way for a broader audience

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed practice and a working understanding of how to interview providers. I also learned how to handle difficult questions and criticism when presenting research, especially surrounding this project since it contains sensitive information. Finally, I learned about the historical and current practices surrounding reproductive care that perpetuate cultural insensitivity among Native American, Black women, and those seeking gender affirming care.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct oral histories, specifically learning about how to interview in a way that allows people to authentically and fully tell their stories. I also learned more about the foundation of gynecology and how the field in the United States starter with experimentation on Black women who were slaves, along with the origins and history of reproductive health care and how we came to be where we are today. A third thing that Iearned was the importance of reproductive justice, along with learning what reproductive justice is and it's three principles.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to contextualize abortion across different settings and populations, navigate difficult conversations surrounding reproductive health and abortion, and communicate reproductive health research to the general public in a digestible format.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about conducting oral history interviews, including writing insightful questions, figuring out how to create new questions based on points that arose throughout interviews and teasing out important things that interviewees may bring up. The interviews also gave me extraordinary insight into what it is like providing reproductive healthcare or advocating for accessible care in a post-Dobbs world. I had a limited understanding of the patient experience, and an even sparser understanding of what providers and advocates are going through. The interviews I conducted and transcribed showed me how much people put at risk - in terms of their safety, livelihood, well-being, and that of those around them - to do their jobs, provide evidence based care and do right by their patients every single day. I also learned more about reproductive healthcare policy and healthcare policy more generally. The course curriculum encouraged us to be up to date on federal and state reproductive health policies, read reports to understand how these policies affect people financially and health-wise, and understand how things like insurance coverage for abortion and reproductive health exacerbate state-by-state disparities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think in deeper, more intersectional ways throughout this course. This class has taught me how to think more deeply about social issues and their impact on reproductive healthcare, autonomy, and people's general lived experiences. Through this class, I've opened my mind to new ways of thinking and have been taught greater empathy and understanding for the people and society around me.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Wesley, Mia, Natalie and Fariha were amazing instructors and always made sure to provide a comfortable learning environment for all, I always felt included and drawn to our class discussions and never felt scared to share something i thought could be polemic. I think discussing how to be respectful when having these conversations was something we often did and helped a lot.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved how we did the check-ins every class, it really felt like we built a lovely, supportive community. I think engaging with Dr. Gray and Dr. Swartz, the OBGYNs on our team, was very helpful as well, due to the insight they provided from their lived experiences and also the connections that they had to others in the reproductive healthcare space gave us great materials for interviews. I would keep this relationship as it made me feel very connected to the work we ere doing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Wesley hosted monthly dinners for class bonding. This encouraged collaboration among our work, and also created a light-hearted environment to support student wellbeing despite working on abortion care research which is arguably a tough, controversial subject manner.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course and facilitator facilitated our learning by letting us engage in hands on research into reproductive healthcare access through out secret shopper in which we called pharmacies across North Carolina, asking about the availability of over the counter birth control and emergency contraception. They also facilitated our learning through guest lecturers who came in and talked about different aspects of reproductive health, including legal, economic, and healthcare aspects. We were also given different mediums through which we ingested information, so rather than just having readings, we also had podcasts to listen to to learn more about reproductive health and abortion access. I think all of these aspects should be kept in future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- In this course I learned how medical anthropology has evolved over the centuries and how the impact of anthropology in medicine has shown a difference in how medicine operates.
Understanding Illness as Culturally Constructed: One of the most impactful insights I gained is that illness is not just a biological event—it’s shaped by cultural beliefs, social systems, and power structures. This helped me see how different societies interpret symptoms, causes, and healing in distinct ways, which really shifted how I think about health and medicine.
Structural Violence and Health Inequities

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of the course was warm, supportive, and highly engaging. Dr. Solomon structured the course to encourage group-based work such as annotating and sharing about texts together and final projects. Additionally, the pass/fail and provided feedback nature of papers, followed by a final graded paper helps foster success among students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the physical structure of the classroom, sitting in a circle promoted discussion and reduced the ability to phase out or get distracted. I liked how some assignments were pass/fail which alleviated pressure and centered the focus on growth. The subtle emphasis on group work throughout the course didn't make it loud and dreadful but encouraged collaboration to further understanding.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

We would openly discuss the readings and connect them to things on campus, in our lives, or in the world in general. Dr. Solomon is very eager and open to hearing your perspective which I greatly appreciated.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Going through the final project too helped greatly illuminate all of the various components that must be considered when trying to get a product to market.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I absolutely love Dr. Clements. He cares so much about his students as people, and he is great at grounding us in the reality of right now. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really liked how we investigated global health in the real world. I think a lot of times global health is presented as a set of statistics which are definitely important to know and understand, but it is equally as important to be able to find solutions to these problems. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class consists of a semester-long group project to design an innovation that mitigates a global health problem your group identifies. Most class periods are spent doing research and designing your innovation with your group. Dr. Clements also brings in interesting guest speakers to talk about their experience designing innovations in global health, and you write a short reflection piece after each guest lecture (graded for completion). It is an easy, interesting class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is an interesting, project-based course that will get you thinking in new ways. Most work is completed during class time, and you work in groups for the entire semester.

Regardless, this course was quite outstanding, both in its material and the professor, and I would certainly recommend it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I'd highly recommend this class for anyone who may be interested in health policy or going into a health profession in the future (aka premeds- you should take this course)! It wasn't a whole bunch of work with the way Prof Campbell set up the course. We had weekly reflections, three assignments spread out throughout the semester, and a final project. The weekly reflections took me longer than I initially thought it would (3-5 hours, including reading the assigned articles + writing), but I learned so much.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Come to class prepared with things to say about the readings and prepare to steer the discussion. If there is something you would like to get out of the class, make that clear. Dr. Campbell was very open-minded and open to feedback.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was a great introduction to the US healthcare system, with complex topics and debates ranging from abortion to healthcare insurance coverage. We discussed the dominance of employer-sponsored insurance and US health spend compared globally. I would recommend the course to anyone interested in health policy, community health, and medicine!

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.

It has been helpful in shaping my understanding of how things like insurance, quality of care etc are managed, which I think are important and applicable to the near future when I have to make health decisions for myself.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also learned about the various considerations that go into policy decisions and that it will be much more difficult to reform healthcare than I previous thought.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed an ability to critically weigh benefits and drawbacks of the American healthcare system, and to evaluate my ideas with sufficient rigor. The latter point was an emphasis of the class, which I greatly appreciated as I potentially consider a career in health policy.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Dr. Ubel's style of "cold calling" students in class helped me to think on me feet, stay engaged, allow my opinions and ideas to be challenged, and use critical thinking skills. Additionally, the "impossible to answer" essay prompts made me think more broadly and precisely.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically think about the US healthcare system. We did this through readings, quizzes, and essays, as well as in class participation. I learned numerous insights into just how complicated the US healthcare system truly is, and how it converges with the field of economics. We studied cost, quality, and access extensively, and critically evaluated what aspects should be tackled in order to fix a flawed system.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about the US healthcare system and its pros and cons. The essays make you question what you think is true and then decide how to best refute opposing views. I learned to be much more critical of what our current systems in place are and that even though the US is doing something does not make it the right thing to do. I also learned to concisely get points across, especially when the topics can be hard to discuss.

course: PUBPOL-165-01 : INTRO TO US HEALTH CARE SYSTM.PUBPOL-165-01.HLTHPOL-165-01.SCISOC-165-01.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my Spanish, learned more about interacting with Latino patients, and really broadened my knowledge about healthcare systems in different countries. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned a lot about Latinx culture, traditions, and beliefs.

3. I learned about health systems in Latin American countries.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-- practice with conversational Spanish, especially in conversations related to healthcare and public health

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
One specific thing I learned was how to take into account multiple different perspectives when considering an issue.
Another specific thing I learned was how to demonstrate cultural competency in my daily interactions with other people.
Another specific thing I learned was the different determinants of health and how those can contribute to inequity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about new perspectives, as well as how to apply the concepts in class to those new perspectives. This class also helped improve how I use my Spanish, especially when speaking on abstract ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I learned about the different healthcare systems of Latin American countries

- I learned about healthcare disparities and how I can play a role in mitigating them

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I've learned various methods of how to apply skills learned on global health into my community and daily life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three things that I developed/learned during the course had to do with the Latino/poc community. I learned about the cultural competence and how its important for people who are trying to go into the medical field because everyone needs to be treated with respect and sometimes working with people from different backgrounds may need for different handling techniques. I also learned about the need for interpreters and translators. Finally, I also learned about the need to speak other languages other than English especially in this ever-growing country.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that acting out of your comfort zone can sometimes be very helpful to other people and although some questions may seem intrusive, they are actually very beneficial to learning about people and their lifestyles. I also learned that cultural competence is not only learning to speak another language but engaging in that culture and that culture mastery can never be achieved. Lastly, I learned that a person in Latina America is in fact, American and that this term should not be used for only those in the United States.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about specific aspects that are similarities among much of latino culture and the vast vast differences that exist within it too (diversity). I learned about the inequities facing latino immigrants in the United States and how that impacts their ability to gain accessible and quality health care. I learned how to best continue improving my cultural competence of latino culture as to increase ability to work with latino people in our community with sympathy and an open-mind.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned various ways to assess the state of public health in Latin communities in the United States and all across Latin America. We learned about the unique health challenges faced by Latin American communities and how medical providers can become more effective and personal in their treatment of Latin patients.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
