question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned about disparities affecting the health of latino people, particularly in the United States
2) My Spanish communication skills improved due to the fact that this was a content-based course taught in Spanish. My vocabulary relating to health topics improved as well.
3) I gained experience participating in service learning for this class. This experience was invaluable as it allowed me to communicate with and learn about the lives of many people living in the Durham community, including many latino people.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Beginning exposure to LatCrit (Latina & Latino Critical Theory)
Analysis of media (ie films/documentaries) 
Conversational and presentation skills in Spanish

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my conversational skills, learned about health disparities among the Latinx population, and engaged with the community in a meaningful way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my spanish skills, develop community relations, and learned a lot about Latino health issues in the US

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about interpersonal communication and building meaningful connections with the Durham community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A greater understanding of Durham and the Spanish/ Latino community here.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class gave me incredible real-world application of common health disparities both in and out of the US. A few main takeaways: learning about the social determinants of health, traditional medicine, and the Latino Paradox.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about social determinants of health in the Latina community. Through service learning, I learned how health and culture interact in the Latina community in Durham.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Specifically, I learned about the extent and dynamics of food insecurity in the country, and especially in North Carolina and Durham. I learned new vocabulary and correcting common grammatical errors that I was making. I also learned about many different service organizations both locally and nationally (such as TCG, Iglesia Emanuel, Root Causes, etc...) that worked to address social determinants of health.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to speak more fluent and conversational Spanish through various modalities inside and outside the classroom. I learned more about the general health disparities that Latine persons face inside and outside of the United States, through various theories/frameworks but also personal stories from communities. Lastly, I learned how these health topics were related to the Latine population in Durham through engaging in and reflecting on service learning with the Latine community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about social determinants of health from the Latino and immigrant perspectives. I learned about how where you live impacts the food you have access to and the amount of daily stress you are under from violence or lack of public parks. I also learned about the immigrant paradox and potential explanations for why recently immigrated Latinos are healthier than Latinos who have been in the US for longer. I also learned about service learning and the value of learning about complex issues alongside actual community engagement.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There was a good balance of lectures, small-group discussions, essays, and quizzes. I felt as though the first portion of the semester was a bit lecture-heavy, but I enjoyed the latter half where we engaged in discussions over materials. I felt like these discussions helped me learn about the material, but they were also more helpful for me regarding my Spanish-speaking skills. I think I'd keep the small group discussions for future years because I found them really helpful and engaging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The multiple presentation activities were really helpful in helping build my confidence in using my Spanish skills in an academic setting. The service learning portion also helped me build confidence using Spanish in real life interactions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Clifford was very patient and flexible with each student. I felt insecure about my Spanish skills in the beginning, but Dr. Clifford was very encouraging. I also enjoyed that the course was very conversational and interesting. We learned about different concepts through different mediums everyday; it wasn't just a lecture every class period.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Joan was forgiving with deadlines and was willing to help in whatever way she could to ensure it was feasible for her students to get their work done. The course prioritized learning the content more so that the final grade which I believe is a good attribute in a class of pre-meds/Global Health/PubPol majors who are aiming to learn how to provide better care or create better polices to improve healthcare outcomes. Joan did a great job covering the complexities of Latino health in America from urban and rural struggles, ACEs, exclusion because of documentation status, mental health, determinants of health, holistic health, and so much more in a way that was understandable in another language, giving us a deep understanding of this community.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor, Joan, was very supportive, kind, and understanding throughout this experience. I would love the course to stay as is in future years, but it will be good to have a clearer understanding of what deadlines are part of the service-learning experience.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Joan facilitated learning by mixing up assignments; this class has a little of everything so as not to bore students with the same format all year round. We had presentations, conversations, essays, readings, and more. I also liked that Joan was flexible on deadlines if you needed more time; this really encouraged real learning and I was able to authentically explore social determinants of health and switch to more interesting topics if desired. My final project is a podcast and I really loved interviewing people and taking the time to connect with the community on what we learned - this would not have been possible without a professor willing to promote students' interests.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: A good amount of the partner organizations work on the weekends or during regular class hours so there may be some conflicts if you have a lot of classes back to back or commitments on the weekends. So, be prepared to manage a long term service commitment around this -- that is have a plan before taking the course that also accommodates your other projected semester commitments (and some wiggle room for unexpected events) to make sure you are able to enjoy that aspect of the class and doesn't become a point of stress.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a little bit drier in the beginning, but it is because there are more readings and lectures to get a foundational understanding of the material that will be discussed throughout the course. Once halfway through the course, it is more about application of that learned knowledge, so it becomes more creative and more fun. The service learning portion also made the course a lot more meaningful and engaging because you are getting the change to directly interact with the community in a way that matters; this engagement also made me want to engage more in the course material so I could apply it in the service learning portion.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You got it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a great class that blends a normal classroom environment and engagement with Durham really well. I think every student should have the opportunity to take a service learning course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course can be a little nerve-racking if you are a non-Native speaker because we discuss such complex issues about health and disease in Spanish. But it is doable. You have to get over your fear over making speaking mistakes because it will happen, but you should definitely try always and persevere. The topics are worth learning for a deserving community.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Useful course to understand the history of the Latina community in Durham and ongoing health challenges. The integration with service-learning is done very well, and the organizations with whom we get paired are invested in our learning. Lots of assignments, each worth a small portion of our grade, makes for an involved but manageable class. Definitely get to practice our Spanish in a healthcare context considerably.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take up an organization you want to be involved in and are interested in, as it facilitates a greater sense of service.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say completely immerse yourself in the course, especially the service-learning, as you will learn more from it than the students you teach/opportunity you volunteer for.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I not only improved my speaking skills in Spanish, but I also learned how to communicate and connect with Latinos of all backgrounds through the service learning portion of this course. Furthermore, it helped me better understand how people of different Latino values differ in their culture, beliefs, and customs, something that also helped me connect with them when I was participating in service learning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Cultural awareness and practical experience working with the Latino community in health-related contexts in Durham
- Increased proficiency discussing complex health-related topics and outcomes

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to interact better with the Spanish speaking residents of Durham.
2. I learned how to better search for information from Spanish sources and think about this information from a variety of viewpoints.
3. I better understand the interactions between healthcare and culture, and healthcare as a general concept rather than a "right" and "wrong" concept.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The health access and availability for Latinx and Hispanic communities. The opportunities that exist in Durham for volunteers to help Spanish populations. The global trends that affect Latinx populations, especially within the US and their impact on immigrants.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

ways to talk about healthcare in spanish - vocabulary

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my conversational abilities in Spanish, learned more complex sentence structures in Spanish, and gained a broad understanding of social determinants of health in Latino communities in the U.S.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Improved Spanish skills, understanding of health from several perspectives, learning across different latin cultures and communities

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the impacts of systemic issues and fundamental cause theories that impact the health of Hispanic and Latin American communities. I improved my grammar and reading/speaking simply by being able to practice and have consistent immersion in Spanish.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think the biggest thing I learned in this course was how to convey my ideas in Spanish as I am speaking with native speakers. I also learned how to gain insights into someone's culture and be a space of empathy and honesty for people. Finally, I think my ability to form complex ideas in Spanish improved throughout the semester as well as my confidence in my own speaking abilities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed intercultural competence and the ability to communicate my thoughts clearly in Spanish.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned the challenges and the barriers that confront the Latino community in the US and Latin American countries. We learned about the Latino Health paradox, acculturation, and assimilation and their effects on Latino health and its connection with immigration. We also constructed and discussed different health policy interventions that can improve Latino health in the US.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I definitely learned how to apply cultural competency to my life, I learned some things to work on for when I go to med school, and I also learned some ways to be more involved in the community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course broadened my understanding of the latinx community in the United States and specifically in Durham. It prompted me to think about societal issues larger than myself and the unique impacts on different minorities with the latinx population. I developed valuable discussion and comprehension skills in Spanish and expanded my conversational level of Spanish to a level where I can discuss more complex issues in depth with diverse vocabulary.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to approach cultural exchanges through a lens of humility and wanting to learn, the knowledge of different health systems around the Latin American world and the issues that many of them face, and the specific health struggles that many immigrants face both here and abroad.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor did a great job facilitating our learning because she made the class environment very comfortable for everyone and made everyone feel like they were an important part of discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course was so thoughtfully designed to increase our cultural competency and humility. Acknowledging the nuance and diversity of Latino culture was emphasized throughout everything we learned. I feel like I’m leaving this class with a much better understanding of how Hispanic populations’ social and cultural contexts impact their health, and what institutional supports/barriers affect their access to healthcare, both here in the United States and in Latin America. Prof. Fernández was an amazing instructor and always made me feel supported in my learning throughout the class!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: First of all, Professor Fernandez was just absolutely amazing.
